column1: Photodynamic therapy (PDT) uses a medicine together with a special type of light to kill cancer cells.

The light triggers the medicine to produce a type of oxygen that treats cancer by: - Killing cancer cells - Damaging blood cells in the tumor - Helping the body's infection-fighting system attack the tumor The light can come from a laser or other source.
PDT treats cancer in the: - Lungs, using a bronchoscope - Esophagus, using upper endoscopy Doctors use light-emitting diodes (LEDs) to treat skin cancers.

For example, it: - Targets only cancer cells, not normal cells - Can be repeated many times in the same area, unlike radiation therapy - Is less risky than surgery - Takes less time and costs less than many other cancer treatments But PDT also has drawbacks.
Also, it cannot be used in people with certain blood diseases.
